meanings.definition: To make a joint leakproof by filling in cracks with oakum or other material.
meanings.sent1: The carpenter calked the ship's hull to prevent water from seeping in.
meanings.sent2: The plumber calked around the bathtub to stop the water leaks.
meanings.sent3: The sailor calked the boat so well that not even a drop of water could sneak in.
meanings.sent4: She calked the window seams tightly, keeping the cold air out.
meanings.sent5: The handyman calked the gaps in the door, making it as tight as a drum.

meanings.definition: To drive a calk into (a seam).
meanings.sent1: He carefully calked the nail into the wood to secure the joint.
meanings.sent2: The blacksmith calked the horseshoe onto the hoof.
meanings.sent3: The farmer calked the fence post to keep it sturdy in the ground.
meanings.sent4: She calked the screw into the wall, making sure it was firmly in place.
meanings.sent5: The carpenter calked the shelf bracket to the wall for extra support.

meanings.definition: To fill the seams of (a wooden vessel) with oakum to make them watertight.
meanings.sent1: The shipbuilder calked the boat to ensure it would float without leaking.
meanings.sent2: The fisherman calked his small boat before setting out to sea.
meanings.sent3: The pirate calked the ship before embarking on their treasure hunt.
meanings.sent4: She calked the canoe before the river expedition to keep it afloat.
meanings.sent5: The sailor calked the rowboat to make sure it wouldn't sink during the storm.
